metadata.title: Wavelet regression and additive models for irregularly spaced data
metadata.author: Asad Haris, Ali Shojaie, Noah Simon
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: We present a novel approach for nonparametric regression using wavelet basis functions. Our proposal, waveMesh, can be applied to non-equispaced data with sample size not necessarily a power of 2. We develop an efficient proximal gradient descent algorithm for computing the estimator and establish adaptive minimax convergence rates. The main appeal of our approach is that it naturally extends to additive and sparse additive models for a potentially large number of covariates. We prove minimax optimal convergence rates under a weak compatibility condition for sparse additive models. The compatibility condition holds when we have a small number of covariates. Additionally, we establish convergence rates for when the condition is not met. We complement our theoretical results with empirical studies comparing waveMesh to existing methods.

highlights: Sardy and Tseng [2004] fit additive wavelet models by treating the data as if regularly spaced; they do not discuss the case when n is not a power of 2
The weights, or coefficients, in such a linear combination are often determined using some form of penalized regression
We develop a proximal gradient descent method for computation of our estimator, which leverages fast algorithms for discrete wavelet transform and sparse matrix multiplication
We begin with a simulation to compare the performance of univariate waveMesh to the traditional interpolation method of Kovac and Silverman [2000], isometric wavelet method of Sardy et al
WaveMesh does not require that covariates are uniformly spaced on the unit interval, nor does it require that the sample size is a power of 2
We proposed an efficient proximal gradient descent algorithm, which leverages existing techniques for fast computation of the discrete wavelet transform
key_statements: Sardy and Tseng [2004] fit additive wavelet models by treating the data as if regularly spaced; they do not discuss the case when n is not a power of 2
The weights, or coefficients, in such a linear combination are often determined using some form of penalized regression
We develop a proximal gradient descent method for computation of our estimator, which leverages fast algorithms for discrete wavelet transform and sparse matrix multiplication
We begin with a simulation to compare the performance of univariate waveMesh to the traditional interpolation method of Kovac and Silverman [2000], isometric wavelet method of Sardy et al
WaveMesh does not require that covariates are uniformly spaced on the unit interval, nor does it require that the sample size is a power of 2
We proposed an efficient proximal gradient descent algorithm, which leverages existing techniques for fast computation of the discrete wavelet transform
summary: Sardy and Tseng [2004] fit additive wavelet models by treating the data as if regularly spaced; they do not discuss the case when n is not a power of 2.
We give a simple proposal that effectively extends wavelet-based methods to nonparametric modeling with a potentially large number of covariates.
We establish adaptive minimax convergence rates similar to that of existing wavelet methods for regularly spaced data.
For regularly spaced data with n = 2J , wavelet bases provide an efficient nonparametric estimator.
We discuss some existing methods for dealing with irregularly spaced data and present our novel proposal, waveMesh.

We discuss some variations and extensions of waveMesh, namely (1) using a conservative order for the wavelet basis expansion, (2) extending waveMesh for more general loss functions and, (3) using a weighted 1 penalty for shrinkage of wavelet coefficients.
In the supplementary material we present additional simulation studies comparing the prediction performance and computation time of waveMesh for various values of K.
We establish rates for the sparse additive waveMesh proposal for a specific penalty.
The constants (s, q1, q2) are the parameters of Besov spaces; for a function g ∈ L2([0, 1]) with the wavelet bases expansion (1), the Besov norm is defined as g = Bqs1,q2 αj0 q1 +
We begin with a simulation to compare the performance of univariate waveMesh to the traditional interpolation method of Kovac and Silverman [2000], isometric wavelet method of Sardy et al.

WaveMesh, the interpolation proposal of Kovac and Silverman [2000] and isometric wavelet proposal of Sardy et al [1999], for a sequence of 50 λ values linear on the log scale and select the λ value that minimizes the mean square error, MpaSraEm=etenr.−W1 efi0m−plefme22n.

For interpolation [Sardy et al, 1999] and isometric [Kovac and Silverman, 2000] wavelet proposals, we use the universal thresholding rule for tuning parameter selection [Donoho and Johnstone, 1994]; this rule leads to near minimax convergence rates like that of Theorem 1.
We again observe that waveMesh outperforms existing methods for a number of simulation scenarios, except for a few cases with polynomial and bumps functions.
WaveMesh reasonably models the data via a smooth function; the interpolation method has a similar but slightly more biased result around 10 to 25 ms.
The main appeal of our proposal is that it naturally extends to multivariate additive models for a potentially large number of covariates
headline: We present a novel approach for nonparametric regression using wavelet basis functions
